item.title: First post at Wordpress.
item.dc:creator: crashtestastronomer
item.content:encoded:
I've decided to move away from blogspot and try out Wordpress instead. So far so good. I'll post things here about python, astronomy and everything else :-)
Cheers.

item.title: Syntax highlighted Python code in a blog.
item.dc:creator: crashtestastronomer
item.content:encoded:
OK, I give up. I don't know how to format source code properly in this blog. Blech.
from numpy import arange,sqrt, random, linalg from multiprocessing import Pool global counter counter = 0 def cb(r): global counter #    print counter, r counter  =1 def det(M): return linalg.det(M) po = Pool(1) for i in xrange(1,3000): j = random.normal(1,1,(100,100)) po.apply_async(det,(j,),callback=cb) po.close() po.join() print counter

item.title: Ubuntu vs Dell Optiplex 760
item.dc:creator: crashtestastronomer
item.content:encoded:
At last I recieved a desktop computer at the observatory where I'm a student. Its a brand new Dell Optiplex 760 with a Core 2 Quad Q8200 with 4GB of ram. We ordered it without an OS (Because you can choose between Windows and Windows and astronomers don't use that) so I took to the task of installing Ubuntu on it. In order to squeeze that last bit of performance out of the system I decided to install a 64bit variant. I've been running Ubuntu 8.10 64bit on my XPS M1530 for almost a year now without major problems so I assumed it would be fine.
The first attempt was with 8.04.3 64bit. The live disk started but the network adaptor and the display wasn't detected properly. I decided hardy was too old for this desktop. This pretty much left 8.10 because I still can't get pyraf 1.8 to run in 9.04 under python 2.6. If you know how to get this running without using multiple python installations PLEASE let me know.
Ubuntu 8.10 64bit was the winner. Everything worked first time. The desktop effects even worked by default (The computer has the onboard Intel gfx chip).
Wow. This machine is really quiet and even under a full load (4 cores running at 100%) the cpu temperatures stay below 50 degrees centigrade. Not too bad methinks. The 22" 2209WA also helps in making my computing experience enjoyable :-)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Have you had any sound issues with a current Ubuntu Install? 10.04 or 11.10?
Unfortunately i don't have that computer anymore. I left the place that gave it to me so I can't say.

item.title: Using a multithreaded Fortran module in python using f2py.
item.dc:creator: crashtestastronomer
item.content:encoded:
This is something I've been wanting to do for a while and TODAY I GOT IT WORKING! This is an example of using a multithreaded fortran subroutine in python. I created the wrapper using the fantastic f2py. The multithreading is done using the OpenMP library. The example calculates a discrete fourier transform using a brute force approach. It may not be the best algorithm but it works. The DFT works for unevenly sampled data and in astronomy we use it often to look for periodicities in the time-series observations we make of variable stars.
Here is all the codes you need to make it work, hopefully :-) I use Ubuntu Linux 8.10 64bit. You're on your own if you use windows, I don't ever use it so I don't know how to make these things work. Save the fortran file as periodogram.f90. Also save the python file into the same directory. Then, inside that directory, run the command "f2py -c -m deemingomp periodogram.f90 --f90flags="-fopenmp " -lgomp". Then run the python script.
I get the following output on my laptop with a Core 2 Duo 2.5 GHz processor:
ewald@ewald-laptop64:/media/bigdrive/programming/f2py_omp/ompdft$ python deeming.wordpress.py Python version : 3.27098703384 Fortran 90 version : 1.31940603256 Fortran 90 OpenMP version : 0.72838306427 ewald@ewald-laptop64:/media/bigdrive/programming/f2py_omp/ompdft$
and this is on my Core 2 Quad Q8200 desktop:
ewald@viper:~$ python deeming.wordpress.py Python version : 3.67803311348 Fortran 90 version : 1.50673294067 Fortran 90 OpenMP version : 0.393154859543 ewald@viper:~$
The speed-up using 2 or 4 cores is pretty good. To run this example you'll need numpy (which comes with f2py) as well as a fortran compiler (I use gfortran from the Ubuntu repos).
Have fun!! Any comments on how to make this better are definitely welcome.
Edit: I've removed the code from the page, check the next post for the github link to where it is available.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I was wondering how to use f2py and openmp together. Nice Example.
Greetings from Turkey. Thank you,
That was a very good example! Please keep on posting =)

Thanks for the post, I am trying to link a f90 code which is parallelized with
f2py -c -m ants ants.f90 --f90flags="-fopenmp -lgomp" --fcompiler=gfortran
This generates a file called ants.so, but when I import it from python I get the error:
ImportError: /home/fforster/Work/f2py/ants.so: undefined symbol: GOMP_single_start
If I don't include the f90flags options I don't get the error and the code runs as expected, but not parallel :(
Any ideas? F

I think you need to install the libgomp1 library. This command will do it:
sudo apt-get install libgomp1
Cheers

Hi!
I was just about to look for an example to show me how to use f2py together with omp.
I did not expect to get this nice comparison! Thanks a lot for posting!
here is my result:
~/Downloads/ompf2py_example$ python deeming.py Python version : 2.51801800728 cython version : 2.06622195244 Fortran 90 version : 2.15363287926 Fortran 90 2nd version : 1.09740996361 Fortran 90 OpenMP version : 1.11975383759 Fortran 90 OpenMP 2nd version : 0.546439886093 py == cy True py == f90 True py == f90_2 False py == f90omp True py == f90omp_2 False
This was computed on an intel xeon 6 core X5660 @ 2.80GHz
Cheers!

item.title: Working on a little something on the side
item.dc:creator: crashtestastronomer
item.content:encoded:
I've always wanted to make a game. Seeing I like flight simulators I though a flying game will be just the thing. Turns out its rather difficult and the amount of free game art available isn't THAT inspiring so I decided to learn to do it all myself, at least until the first simple demo works. Seeing that I'm South African and our airforce used Mirage fighters for a long time, I decided to make a flying game featuring a Mirage F1 jet. Here's a pic of my Blender model as it stands now:

 

Here's what my model looks like now.

 

As for the game, I decided to do it in Python using the Panda3d engine.  I've got a very basic toy flying around a simple map at the moment. I'm still figuring out how to make certain components work e.g. the flight model, which I have running using JSBSim and its python bindings as well as how to make large terrains without bringing my laptop to a halt. I need to add collisions and all that too.

The next big problem will be the development of a believable flight model for my Mirage. There isn't one on Flightgear I can borrow so I've decided to make one using the "datcom" program. But thats for another day...

item.title: Building my own guitar valve amplifier...
item.dc:creator: crashtestastronomer
item.content:encoded: Yes, I'm doing it. I've decided to build one. Spend money on stuff, have fun putting them together, have fun using it. There's an extra layer of fun in there :D First thing I'm doing is using this schematic: from which I am have created created this layout: Its not done yet, but I'll post progress here as I go along. Its done now, just needs some final checking for mistakes. If you spot a mistake or think the layout can be improved in any way, please shout. cheerio

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Thomas Selmer-Olsen :

Hey Ewald

Nice going so far! Just a note, some people use a 150R 5W cathode bias resistor rather than the 130R for a bias more suitable for modern tubes.

But killer stuff!

Thomas

Right, That explains the big ass 150 Ohm resistor I have :D I'll use that one instead.

It's the best moment to produce some plans for the future and it's time to be happy. I have read this article and if I could I desire to suggest you some interesting things or suggestions. Maybe you could write next articles mentioning to this article. I desire to read more things about it! Tommie Oxley

Hey Ewald
Nice going so far! Just a note, some people use a 150R 5W cathode bias resistor rather than the 130R for a bias more suitable for modern tubes.
But killer stuff!
Thomas
